That's wonderful! Creating a bird-friendly habitat in your backyard is a great way to support local bird populations and enjoy the beauty of nature right in your own yard.

**Native Species:**

Planting native species is an excellent way to attract birds, as they provide the right food, shelter, and habitat for local bird species. Native plants have co-evolved with native birds, so they're perfectly suited to meet their needs.

**Birdbath:**

Maintaining a birdbath is another great way to attract birds, as they need water for drinking and bathing. Make sure to keep the birdbath clean and well-maintained to prevent the spread of disease.

**Downy Woodpeckers and White-breasted Nuthatches:**

Congratulations on attracting these wonderful bird species to your yard! Downy Woodpeckers and White-breasted Nuthatches are both common visitors to backyards with native vegetation and birdbaths.

**Tips for Creating a Bird-Friendly Habitat:**

1. **Diversify Your Plantings:** Incorporate a variety of native plants, including trees, shrubs, and flowers, to provide a range of habitats and food sources for different bird species.
2. **Provide Suet and Seed:** Offer suet and seed to attract birds during the winter months or when natural food sources are scarce.
3. **Create a Brush Pile:** Leave a brush pile or a small area of your yard unmanicured to provide shelter and habitat for birds.
4. **Reduce Lawn Area:** Consider reducing the size of your lawn to make way for more native plantings and habitat diversity.
5. **Avoid Pesticides:** Refrain from using pesticides, which can harm birds and other wildlife, and instead adopt natural methods to control pests.

**Certifying Your Yard:**

Consider certifying your yard as a wildlife habitat through programs like the National Wildlife Federation's Certified Wildlife Habitat or the Audubon Society's Bird-Friendly Habitat. These programs provide guidance on creating a bird-friendly habitat and recognize your efforts to support local wildlife.

By following these tips and continuing to maintain your birdbath and native plantings, you'll be well on your way to creating a bird-friendly habitat that attracts a variety of bird species to your yard!
